page.title: Basic, Single-Clause Sentences - Pro-Drop and Imperative
page.introduction:
Some languages are pro-drop languages which allow a subject and/or object to be missing. For example, in Spanish the normal way to say “I buy a book” is Compro un libro rather than with the overt subject pronoun included: Yo compro un libro. This is not allowed in English, except for imperatives. (The missing subject of infinitives in embedded complements will be considered in
Complement Clauses.)
Some languages are not really pro-drop languages, but at least some of the pronouns are clitics which can attach to the verb. When this happens, there is no pronoun or nominal phrase in subject position, so the sentence looks the same as in a true pro-drop language.

radioGroup.radio: No, like English, the subject must be overt except in imperatives

form.instruction: In the lexicon, mark any affixes that indicate imperative and any inherently imperative verbs with the feature imperative.

All of the pronouns that may attach as subject clitics need to have the appropriate agreement features added in the lexicon. If a particular pronoun can stand alone in subject position and also may attach to the verb, add both sets of features, e.g. first singular first_subject singular_subject.

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language have object agreement marking on the verb to allow pro-drop of the object?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, pro-drop of the object is also allowed
